comments.commentBody: The stunning photograph of the refugees seeking safety reminded me of my father's escape from Turkey nearly 100 years ago. He was 5-years-old when his mother, fearing an attack by the Ottoman Turks against the Greeks living on the coast of Turkey, gathered up her children, hired a boat and late at night fled from that very same coast to the Island of Lesbos. Eventually, they reunited with his father who had already made his way to Peabody, Massachusetts. His great-grandsons now live in Boston.

Yes, those countries certainly provided well for their citizens; like torturing and murdering them in every which way possible.

And I hate to burst your fantasy bubble further, but there are wars raging in the mideast that actually have NOTHING to do with the Us or Europe.
Wrong country;
International Red Cross exists.
Seems like the kind of thing the Red Cross would be helping with?
Only squalor awaits them? Surely the New York Times realizes that squalor is vastly preferable to being constantly subjected to barrel bombing....

I was a picky eater and so was my sister. My mom once let me not eat, and I didn't eat for 3 days apparently - subsisted on milk. We almost never had processed food or candy at home. Fresh cooked veggies were served at every meal, which I refused to eat even if chained to the table. Many many years later I outgrew this aversion and could now be pretty much vegetarian if necessary without any problems. I guess my point is just that some kids really do have innate food aversions, so long as the parents model good food habits and don't always reach for junk hopefully they will learn. My own kids are starting to get picky - I do let them choose, but from relatively healthy food. At present the only fruit my oldest will eat (she is indeed a very high strung child) eat is papaya, while the young one (very relaxed, not high strung) would happily subsist on rice and eggs. Typical foods they like include tofu, rice, eggs, home fried stir fry or battered chicken (not deep fry) - they refuse veggies except for edamame although as babies they ate loads of veggies. And no, we don't keep ice cream or chips around - and the only regularly available beverage is water. No fruit juice, no Coke, not even milk on a regular basis. But still, they've developed picky food profiles.

.
And Kiki, you AUTO be on the parole for providing the video.

I mean, the *payroll*!

Darn AUTOcorrect.

Good effort to blame Turkey for all things wrong in that pert of the world. But, if someone enters your country as a "transit" person you may not legally retain him there to protect your neighbor from the burden. That would be against the intention law. Furthermore, all migrants departure points are not in Turkey.

I agree with the first part of your comment but have to say that there were over a million Iraqi refugees in Syria in 2006. And there are over two million Syrian refugees in Turkey and Jordan now. I don't know whether they want/settled in their host countries or not but given the fact that migrants and refugees arriving in Europe are nowhere near millions, I would say that the burden is on Muslim-majority countries. This is not to say that I do not feel bad for Greece that has to deal with the influx of destitute people in addition to their existing issues.

This is a horrifying story. What is this, year 1640? Where are the wealthy governments of the region? The UN? Where is anybody?

Greece is barely holding together and they they have to deal with an influx 15,000 desperate refugees a month? We couldn't handle 15,000 per month.

How much are we spending bombing ISIS? We just spent 1/2 billion to train less than 60 Syrian fighters who promptly fell apart. But yet, there is no money for portapotties and food for these poor people. No tents.

Why don't the mighty wealthy gulf nations help. They spend untold fortunes financing madrassas and exporting their toxic Salafi Islam, but yet can't buy something to eat for these unfortunate masses.

We have made a terrible mess of things over there. The resident nations have all contributed to further their own selfish agendas.

Notice that none of the refugees want to settle in an Islamic country. What does that indicate? It indicates the close knit brotherhood of the Islamic people don't care about their own. They are all one nation when it comes to wreaking havoc in the world, but but when people are dying at sea, it's who are those guys? Do we know them?

Everyone is everyone else's pawn. Loyalties are purchased. Everyone is in charge and no one is in charge. This is the sorry condition of the Middle East. That's why no one cares about these people or tries to do anything to alleviate their suffering.

G.P.
I wish I knew what this mysterious message meant. Can you or someone translate it for me?
Well I guess squalor beats torture and death.

It's easy to take the side of the refugee if you only see their side of the story. The fact is taking on migrants is a strain and choosing to help has its own cost. Refusing to help should

This is why the US border with Mexico is so fortified.
Yvonne...the problem is that most are economic migrants...not people fleeing genocide

I am saddened by the plethora of comments throwing easy judgement upon these people who are so desperate to leave their countries. Seriously, would this number of people disrupt their lives and take large risks if things were ok at home? I doubt it. If everyone would take a pause, and picture yourself living in extreme violence, with little employment, vast corruption and no hope for the future, ask yourself what would you do?

I get it - there are many root causes to this chaos, no simple answers and certainly no buckets of cash being put forward to help. Let's just all be a bit more kind in our judgement of our fellow humans.

Turkey hosts two millions Syrian refugees, Lebanon about three-quarter of a millions, Jordan probably a half million. Those are from a war-torn country.
Economic refugees choose more prosperous countries to migrate with the hop of getting a job and making a safe, and economically secure life.

It will not be over Greece. Trade routes maybe.
Here be the challenge of engineers, you have enough in your own land to sustain your own. Why come our way?

This could very well be the beginning of the next global conflict -- WWIII -- Migrants are forced back or fired upon.  Turkey invades some of the Greek Islamds to "protect" fellow Muslims.  Then warfare.

in reply to Nathan Means who comments, "By your logic, Americans are not allowed to take positions on almost any political oppression in the world today."

To the contrary, I believe we all have a right to comment, often an obligation. What I note, though, is the hugely different response among Commenters to Israeli-Palestinian violence and that in Iraq, Syria, Somalia, and elsewhere, as well as to occupations in Tibet, the Crimea, and elsewhere. I am not questioning the motives of individual Commenters. However, the collective disproportionate response is indicative of something.

I am genuinely interested in what you and others might make of that disproportionate response.
Is it because he is associated with two guys named FRED?

Perhaps Keynesian macro has not been established as gospel truth, but Lucas's rational-expectations version has been destroyed by events. At some point the question becomes, why exactly is it that these zombies won't lie down?

After it killed a few chickens, some goats and finally a cow....no one socialized by fires at night; no one dared stroll over to a neighbor’s homestead.

Not that anyone would ever accuse rural agrarian societies of being superstitious. It sounds to me just like the over the top vilification of wild predators by all rural societies.

You don't realize that the same people who are lambasting the poaching of this animal are people who decry the deforestation of the American countryside and the hunting to extinction of not only the mountain lion but also the wolf and other predators.

No sir, you are not permitted to say the I have no right to speak, because someone else deforested my countryside. I suggest that you get your country in order and deal with your political violence. The lion, and the elephant, and the rhinoceros are not responsible for your hunger.

An animal in the wild is not a threat to people as it is close to dwellings.
It's not the lovable and harmless nature of the animal which frustrates me, it's the unnecessary waste of a life that had achieved under the natural obstacles to it's survival just to tickle the fancy of a man who derived a sense of power from killing it without engaging in any real risk to do so nor to protect any other lives, either.

I met a man who had a standing stuffed Alaskan Brown bear in his den and another bear skin on the floor. He bragged of how a professional hunter took him to a frozen lake in a helicopter, sat him in a portable chair, and then chased a bear down to where he could shot it from the chair. He loved it! Why did he love it? He did not hunt the bear. He did not risk being slain by the bear. He killed a bear. Some people call it sport. I call it a thrill of having the power to casually kill a big animal that outlived all the natural things that killed all the other bears who did not survive as did he.
As we should, rightly so. Why wouldn't we.
Do you have issues dealing with facts?
from reading through it - not really. But it may be worth pointing out that a large share of the problem is home-made as the population of Zimbabwe has increased 6 fold since 1950.
Of course, now we will see lots of comments from people who blame this writer and other humans for "invading" the lions' homeland.  Wait for it.

The killing of this lion surely has different meaning to different people dependent upon their individual circumstances.  It's certainly your right to applaud the killing of a carnivorous wild animal that threatens your family and friends.  The thousands of people around the world decrying the lion's killing don't share your experience.  They see that lion having the right to live its life unburdened by insensitive sport hunters who kill only for enjoyment and trophies.  These same people may question your people's choice to live in close proximity to lions.  Perhaps your village existed before the wildlife conservation areas that fostered lion populations were created?  Still, you surely must know the dangers that lions present in any African area where lions exist and perhaps then a fence might have been a way to protect your village.  From both viewpoints, motive is the key and your applause, while righteous, doesn't outweigh their disgust.

You serious? Nzou's mewling, wrong-headed and selfish screen was contemptible. As other writers here have noted, he confuses and conflates several things and draws poor conclusions. What a silly column.

This young man makes a point well worth our attention. The American feel-good-about-your-protest movement is consistently misdirected. Cecil, several hundred pounds of beautiful, living flesh was killed by a coward out for 'sport'. Happens all the time, and is an abomination. However, in the larger scale of reality of residents of Zimbabwe - and many other countries - our concern and outrage about Cecil is absurdist to the point of cruelty.

Is it because the problems are so intractable that we will not focus on them and turn, instead, to small victories against violence and oppression? Is it a lack of compassion and empathy for our fellow humans, people with identical DNA and slightly different skin pigment? Is it a self-righteous preoccupation with ourselves and our ravenous appetite for consumption? We hide our heads in the sand - all of us. Making heroes out of cowards with big bucks and lethal weapons; leaving billions to go hungry and exploited right under our internet and TV empowered noses.

Walk a mile or two in the hot sand and the mud. Get your worldview into sharper focus. Thank you, Mr. Nzou.
Understandable indeed, but one caveat:  I don't remember deep cleavage from the 1950s, and not normally bare shoulders.
I don't thinkk he selling Americans short the overwhelming majority of Americans couldn't find Zimbabwe on a map, sure they're magnificent animals but so is the louse and the flea.

I am an English learner. I am often confused by the usage of "the" before a abstract noun. You wrote, "for the planet, for injustice, for the voiceless". Why don't we use "the" before injustice?

By the way, I like the rhythm of your writing.
"As an islander from the Third World," is a markedly racist comment. But your Western savior complex would not allow you to see that.

Sorry Goodwell, but we dont just cry for lions. As humans, we cry for the planet, for injustice, for the voiceless, for the loss of beauty, for all the evil in this world. As a physician, I understand your logical, scientific thinking. As an islander from the Third World, I understand how annoyed you feel about others romanticizing your country. But as an artist, I mourn Cecil's loss. There are many sides to this debate, and I was happy to read yours. But don't insult us by thinking all Americans think of Africa as Disney. You are selling us as short as you think we are selling you.

It is unrealistic to put a buffer between the animals and farms and villages. The animals in Zimbabwe are everywhere except the main cities. On most of the main highways you do not drive at night for fear of running into anything from an Impala to an Elephant.

When your children and grandchildren grow up will they be spending thousands of dollars a day to view the 4 legged animals or the poor downtrodden two legged ones?

For Mr. Nzou this may be a cultural contrast, but there are 6 billion us, 2 legged creatures and a few thousand lions in limited, quickly diminishing habitats. Another abhorrent fact is that someone paid $50,000 to take a life for fun, using trickery. They specifically lured the lion from the protected zone to stick an arrow into it. The sportsmanship just overwhelms me.

Should there be a buffer zone between villages and protected animal preserves? Probably yes, but that's a different question for local authorities. We, simple Americans, would like to hope that may-be when our children and grandchildren grow up and can pay tens of thousands of dollars to visit on a safari countries like Zimbabwe where people live on less than a dollar a day, and lions are definitely better fed than locals, they (our children and grandchildren) would still get to see lions and cubs and other g-d's four legged creatures that haven't been wiped out by bipeds.

"the complex interplay of Africa's bio system. We spent time in the bush and saw the negative impact of too many predators"?

Are you kidding?

Too many predators? Like lions and tigers? Maybe you should read some NEWS about how they'[re nearing extinction (along with rhinos, elephants, etc, etc) and knock off the "adventure" safaris?

I would highly recommend that you listen carefully to Allan Savory's Ted Talk which repudiates the idea of man balancing nature. He he had himself originated this theory and feels it is one of his biggest mistakes. You will then understand that what you heard as bush gospel is a rationalization to propagate hunting.

My wife and I have just returned from a work trip to Southern Africa. We understand the outcry against the hunt, but are saddened by the ignorance of many westerners to the complex interplay of Africa's bio system.  We spent time in the bush and saw the negative impact of too many predators, too little rain and poor game management. In addition we saw the desperate poverty of many in poorly governed areas.  We also met Africans with an excellent understanding of how to apply layered, patient and wholistic solutions to issues facing their nations. in order for lions and rhinos and other creatures to thrive much more must be done than simply stating that all hunting should be banned. Functional legal systems, accountable governments and growing economies that don't rely primarily on adventure tourism and illegal poaching will do more than all the Twitter campaigns and hateful speech toward hunters will ever achieve.
